Definition: Classify the given comment whether it conveys anything impolite, offensive, or mockingly abusive by providing "insult" or "non-insult".

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: I guess when you're clueless you stick your head into every hole.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Hillary Clinton was not my girlfriend.

I did not have sexual relations with that woman.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be obscene but not insult.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: She is weak and useless, time to run her off
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is disrespectful.

Comment: I want to separate out the nonsense of the Kathy Griffins and Ted Nugents of the world from stuff that really matters. Show business people are, for the most part, self-indulgent children, and the fact that technology gives them all kinds of platforms these days doesn't mean they are worth paying attention to.

But what elected officials say and do does matter. I'm not so naive as to believe there ever was a time in U.S. history when politicians were governed by either civility or honesty, but the wildcard today is the immediate impact their words can have, and rarely for good.

Trump's insomnia-driven tweets aren't harmless. One stupid comment from him at 4 a.m. can dominate the news cycle for the next 24 hours, putting Democrats into response mode and Republicans into damage control mode. And while all that's happening, the work of the country isn't getting done.

This president's lack of personal discipline exhausts Congress, the media and the nation. And that's not a good thing.

Comment: "...“We can say to the alt-right and the neo-Nazis and the KKK: Get over it, you’re African, OK?”..."

Genetically she's correct, but practically she's not.  Read a really good book about two decades ago where the author tried to explain why there are cultural differences between our races.  He basically boiled it down to location.  Races that lived in the more moderate or tropical climates had many means of accessing food and the challenges by the weather for shelter was minimal.  The necessity for technology was minimized.  Cultures in climates farther away from the equator had to not only fight for resource but also develop technologies to advance in the harsher conditions.  Seemed pretty interesting.  It certainly doesn't mean someone from an equatorial climate couldn't successfully enter the more technological environment.  But, there isn't as much necessity for it.

Trump's an idiot in many ways, with or without racist behavior.

Comment: The point is that you have no freedoms. They have become an illusion. At best, you have government-permitted privileges, which means they can be taken away at the whim of the next president. Which of the two idiots running for the major parties is most likely to regulate your pretend freedoms out of existence? I honestly can't tell myself. I think both of them think some "freedoms" need to be curtailed, though they may disagree on which ones. Maybe the next one, like the current one, will only do away with freedoms that I enjoy, so it won't matter to you and you can go on being a PROUD American. But when they get around to taking away the freedoms you consider valuable, then you'll protest.

But there will likely be nobody left with any actual freedom to act to take those freedoms back. While you bargain away freedoms for security, remember ... once they're gone, it takes the blood of patriots & tyrants to get them back. Better not to bargain them away in the first place.

Comment: Calling Trump "Jacksonian" is idiotic.  Yes, Jackson was the first national politician to mobilize a non-moneyed constituency.  But when Jackson became president in 1829, he was not only a famous military hero.  He had also served in both houses of Congress and as military governor of the Florida territory.  He knew well, and was known by, all of the prominent political figures of his day.  And, in office, Jackson displayed a deep grasp of the Constitution and a determination to defend it against the growing possibility of secession.

None of this, of course, is true of Trump, who never served in the armed forces, never served in (or even ran for) public office, and apparently doesn't even pay income taxes.  Trump has never shown the slightest interest in the Constitution.  He has always been a political groupie, hanging around conventions for whatever scraps of attention he could pick up and engaging in scams like the Birther Lie.  He is no more like Jackson than Sarah Palin is.

As he said, the PM not some subordinate non-elected functionary is responsible for the ethical standards and conduct of the government.

Comment: Out, Lane county employees fall into the norm for age. Here is some information I got from our HR folks this morning:

Based on an article from the State of Oregon Employment Department (2016 data from the Census Bureau): 

For the State of Oregon = 23% of workers are >55 For Lane County overall = 25% of workers are >55 Lane County as an organization = 24% of regular status workers are >55 (25% of our workforce is >55 if you count all PERS eligible employees which includes Extra Help and Temps)

Comment: I am not a politician, so I don't need to report it, but I also participated in a Pacifica Institute trip to Turkey.  The article stated, “It’s puzzling that state legislators who rarely get involved in foreign policy matters have been courted with international trips."  Well, I'm not even a legislator!  Why would I get involved?!

The movement "Hizmet" focuses on "service to humanity – regardless of one’s faith, tradition, gender, or ethnicity."  We visited K-12 schools, a university, a newspaper, businesses, and, yes, the fabulous treasures that make up Turkey's rich cultural history. There was no quid pro quo.  I didn't have to sign any papers, or make promises I couldn't keep.  I would simply say that the purpose of the trip was for me (and the others in my group... no politicians) was to have a better understanding of Turkey.  No guide or lecturer bad-mouthed the government (either government).

So the question could be...  should MORE politicians take advantage of this trip?!

Comment: About 15 years ago my daughter was in an extended French school in Mississauga. She was in grade 5 at the time and she forgot her lunch so I headed over to the school to drop it off. What I noticed was that other parents too were dropping off their children's lunches. 
What astounded me was the number of Macdonalds and pizza containers that were piled up in the front office. These were the lunches  that parents were purposely providing for school age children. 
On top of that, every Wednesday was pizza day so, we knew that meal was a write off. I don't have an issue with schools eliminating junk food from school property. It's the parents we have to really be concerned with.

Comment: It is fascinating to see the mission creep of some activists in recent Canadian history.

In the 1970s, violence against women was seen to include acts such as punching and shoving and shooting and such.

By the 1980s, in the wake of the Montreal Massacre, spoken words were added to the list, and violence against women was placed on a spectrum where men who raised their voice in anger, or who ever used pejorative words to refer to a woman, were included among those guilty of violence against women.

Fast forward to 2017, and now violence against women is to include supporting having restrictions against abortion on demand.

Perhaps by the year 2030 we can look forward to having violence against women include not having gender quotas in government, leaving the toilet seat up, and forgetting anniversaries.

That is not a rude or inappropriate comment. Activists are rendering the term "violence" MEANINGLESS with their endless mission creep. Stop it. Use the word violence for VIOLENCE.

Comment: According to a Mar. 2015 article from another TO newspaper there were just over 20,000 asylum.or refugee claims made by illegal border crossers in 2012. One wonders what the total numbers will be this year and how Ottawa will find the cash to support their ongoing needs - food, shelter, education, job training, legal bills, health and dental care etc - when they can't seem to find the funds to lift so many of OUR urban poor out of poverty.

Comment: It appears new resident Joseph P. Mayer Jr. has been given fake news regarding illegal vacation rentals in Hawaii.  There has never been "piled up" applications  for B&B hotels that were not processed. On Oahu, vacation rentals are legal and allowed in resort zoning, but are illegal in all other zoning, including residential. Unfortunately in recent years, scofflaw mainland-companies such as Airbnb and VRBO have been recruiting Hawaii residential property owners (many out-of-state investors) to open-up illegal vacation rentals in our neighborhoods. Housing studies show these illegal rentals reduce our residential housing supply and increase housing cost for our residents. Neighbors have also documented that these hotel-like businesses changes the residential character of their neighborhoods by displacing neighbors with a revolving door of strangers. A "win-win" situation is to keep residential-zoning for residential use and keep vacation rentals in resort-zoning only.

Comment: The Conservatives are in deep trouble because their base remains divided between  social conservatives, who. for example, oppose abortion rights and immigration,  and  economic conservatives,  who largely agree with the Liberals on  social policy but oppose their spending madness.  Harper's talent was in somehow keeping this coalition together, but, in the  end, his need (or desire) to fulfill some elements of the social  conservative agenda, cost him the Red Tory vote that bled to the Liberals rather than to the NDP.

The question is whether the return of a "Progressive"  Conservative Party, purged of its Reform elements, would gain more votes from the centre than it would lose among social conservatives.  The dominance of the Liberals after the Reform Party was created, suggests the  answer, but the Liberals  of the 1990s displayed more fiscal responsibility than the previous and subsequent Trudeau regimes.   This may create a new opportunity for a Red Tory revival.

Comment: What do you mean by 'capital gains are taxable to the U.S.??

If you hold a dividend paying U.S. stock in a TFSA, the dividends are subject to U.S. withholding tax and this is not recoverable (it is recoverable for most taxpayers in a non-registered account via the Foreign Tax Credit). However, any capital gains on a U.S. stock in a TFSA are not subject to either Canadian or U.S. capital gains taxes.

Comment: You are right, nice example.  I would like to add that your example implies a forced sale or foreclosure, with the bank suing to make up the differential.  All fine.  The deeply underwater owners can then go bankrupt, and probably would, rather than slaving for years to pay the bank.  The underwater percentage was a lot larger in many US cases, killing all hope of hanging on.  BUT the major point is that owners can walk away BEFORE the bank even forecloses/fails to renew. That is how the US fell so fast - voluntary default, mail in the keys, walk away.  Then wait a year and buy back the same house for 40% less!  Nice!  In the Canadian case you probably have to declare bankruptcy - which will happen!  When you can get out from under $400k of after-tax debt, do it! In fact, the more recently the buyers purchased, and the lower their DP , the less equity they have, and the more incentive they will have to walk.  No loss! I'm gone!

Comment: Here's my strategy:
1) My wife and I take CPP at 60 - we retired in our 50s.
2) Invest the money - max out our TFSAs, with the rest in a standard investment account.
- using this strategy, based on a 6% return, I calculate a net worth benefit until well into our mid-80's.
- after that, net worth is negatively impacted, but not dramatically
3) Use the TFSAs as supplemental medical and long term care funds, if needed
- do not buy supplemental medical insurance or long term care insurance - a further net worth improvement, if the funds are not required
4) With the first death, the surviving spouse's CPP will revert to the max, restoring the CPP reduction caused by taking it early
- a little life insurance for the surviving spouse

Comment: The only moral principle that should be respected in cases like this is that no political entity should be kept intact by force. In other words, if a majority of citizens in any geographic area vote in a fair referendum to leave a political union, they should be able to do so. This principle must be applied consistently. For example, if the majority of Quebec voted to leave Canada, they must be allowed to separate. However, if the majority of a smaller area such as Montreal voted to leave Quebec, this should also be respected. The noted Austrian economist and libertarian, Ludwig Von Mises, called this the "unlimited right of secession". A state must never be forced on any of its territories.

Comment: All of this is probably true. Having begun to read the parliamentary committee's report, there are seemingly other obstacles and challenges. First, the committee promises an ecological or systemic analysis, but fails to look first at the desired role of parliament in the 21st century as a first logical step in analyzing the question of how we might reform the process of choosing members of Parliament. Second, and likely most important, the Parliamentary committee is made up of members of political parties, and their work reflects their fundamental, and seemingly unquestioned, belief in the necessity and importance of political parties in Parliament. Third, there does not appear to be any analysis of the changing nature of Canada in the 21st century, and how this might lead to a changing Parliament, outcomes, functions, and people. Fourth, the two fairness issues (i.e. the local riding vote and the political national vote) become so intertwined that it is impossible to pull them apart.

Comment: Mountain bikes and hikers/walkers are a bad mix in beautiful areas. Mountain bikers seek thrills, but the other folks precisely wish to avoid that. Quiet, a true nature experience, and a communion with the natural environment are impossible on a machine that can reach speeds over 10mph, especially downhill. Need I point out that mountain bike tires, with their knobbiness, destroy dirt trails by increasing erosion and by chewing up the ground?
Mountain bikes should heavily be restricted; these trails were not created for them, they all originally were for walking/hiking. Let the mountain bike lobbyists pay for new trails, for their upkeep (it will be considerable considering the mitigation necessary because of our long, wet winter/fall seasons), and their improvements. 
Folks who confuse hiking trails with the issues of cars and pavement and dogs and hiking need beginning classes in logic (and having your dog off-leash happens to be against rules in many areas).

Comment: The empirical evidence is overwhelming to support the contention that nicotine is "highly addictive" as the author states.

But where is the evidence that such a "highly addictive" substance can be reduced to "non addicting levels"?  People don't start smoking a pack a day.  Even the low level of nicotine consumed by beginning smokers is quickly addictive.  Reducing the amount of nicotine in cigarettes would be the opposite of harm reduction when smokers inevitably compensate by smoking more of them.  Also, how do you convince young people not to start smoking when cigarettes are branded as not being addictive?

I could understand raising taxes on cigarettes to push people towards vaping as a harm reduction strategy, but this idea of cutting nicotine is really hard to rationalize.  Unless of course it's a way for tobacco companies and governments who are addicted to cigarette taxes to continue to sell large numbers of smokes to a decreasing number of smokers.

Comment: not lying...surgical floor - not critical.  i think most everybody up there was getting released soon.  they did have a few new arrivals up to the point of the multi injury thing.  i was pretty well onto recovery and scooting around on my own - kept there an extra day because of muscle spasms.  full knee replacement, day 2 post op and i'm ditching the walker as much as possible.  i did not see my nurses except for" junior"nurse (no slight intended - proper term escapes me) for blood pressure and pulse ox checks as i think they called it.  i saw my reg nurse for meds and as i was getting released.  she spent a few minutes asking how i was doing, getting around, short chat. very pleasant and i never felt neglected. if i hit the buzzer someone showed up pretty quick. the last day i just took responsibility and got myself all ready for discharge.  but yeah  - she DID have that patient load - she said it was unusual and the the multi injury didn't help,  but it was handled.

Comment: For the record, I am an Investment Advisor. May I recommend following some of the advice that has been written in the G&M; look up investment firms/ planning firms that have offices locally or nearby; check them out online; schedule an interview with an advisor; give them a clear vision of what you are looking for and the services you would like; find out their background and experience; ask them about the type of clients they deal with; then if you find someone whom you feel comfortable with (after checking him/her out online -see if there are any regulatory issues, etc), provide them with you investment info and have  a proposal showing all costs and services, etc. Then if it seems to be a good fit, tell your former firm to politely(or not) to take a hike. After all, It's your money.  If the advisor doesn't see it being a good fit, hopefully they will refer you to someone whom they feel would suit your needs. Good luck!

Comment: Seriously, did you even read the article? No? Here, let me help you out.

To graduate Cum Laude, you must score a 3.75 GPA. This means that you have to score 3 As and one B for every 4 courses you take. A C requires 7 As to counter. A D requires 11 As. An F would require  15 As to counter. Since you only have 56 courses to work with, you have to bust your butt...

Summa Cum Laude requires a 3.9 GPA. This means that every 9 courses out of 10 must be an A, and the 10th can't be lower than a B. A C would require 19 As, and a D would require 29. You CAN manage a 3.9 with an F, but 39 out of your 56 courses must be As, and a second F would doom your chances of getting this. 

Magna Cum Laude cannot be achieved without taking Honors or AP courses. You must score a 4.1 GPA, which means that you must take 1 Honors course for every 10 classes, and score As in all of them! 

Not every tom, dick, and harry will be walking out of high school with an Honors Degree.

Comment: To be fair, I think the "slim chance" of conviction means a slim chance of convicting on the highest possible charge, rather than a conviction at any level. For instance, there might be a slim chance to convict of first degree murder, but greater chance at second degree or manslaughter. In some cases an accused might be willing to plea bargain on the lesser (but still serious) charge, but fight all the way to avoid a longer prison sentence. I doubt if Alberta prosecutors are generally sending cases with a slim chance of conviction to trial.

Comment: I feel no dismay at Sessions or his comments, i simply disapprove of them just as I disapprove of any prevarication and falsehood uttered about Hawaii.
Anyone who has lived anywhere in the country understands the difference between a person who is local and a transplant. Generally speaking the views of people who are born and raised in a locale matter more than someone who is from somewhere else regarding said locale. Why? Because they are born and raised, from that place and have an investment. The transplant does not and therefore lacks the knowledge and appreciation of the local. That's the way it has been in other places I have lived like Los Angeles and Seattle. In that sense it is no different here in Hawaii. I never asserted that my view of LA was somehow the right one when I lived there nor did I think I knew more about the Capital Hill neighborhood of Seattle I lived in than did those raised there.
As for the other comments, those premises are off topic.
Your premise fails.

Comment: "For his part, Rodriguez argued that government mismanagement that has created so many problems for Puerto Rico is showing itself again as it attempts to deal with the devastation from the hurricane.

“For instance, shortly after the hurricane hit, the government imposed a curfew from 6 pm to 6 am and then changed it,” Rodriguez said. “Now, it’s 7 pm to 5 am, and makes no sense. The curfew has prevented fuel trucks from transporting their loads.

“These trucks should have been allowed to run for 24 hours to address our needs, but they have been stalled, and so we have massive lines at gas stations and severe shortages of diesel at our hospitals and supermarkets.”

Rodriguez said it is the federal government that has put forth an organized response, and that it is wrong of Puerto Rico’s own political leaders to blame it.

Don’t let the Puerto Rican government play the victim and fool you. They have no clue what they are doing... they will mishandle anything that comes their way.”

Comment: While there are those who will obsess over spelling, this is a dramatic editorial marking one of the greatest moments in American and world history.  Perhaps one had to have lived through the era of WWII to understand it's significance.  The recent retro reprint of the RG's front page after the invasion brought back memories  hopeful yet fearful for the success of Normandy--the immediate  future of freedom in Europe-- and eventually America-- was in the balance. 
It's hard, I realize, for younger people who grew up in our messy wars in Viet Nam, Iraq, etc. to comprehend that there was a time we were truly fighting for our lives and not for oil or dominance.  And I say "we" because most all of us felt involved in this effort.  
I doubt that we'll ever experience such a united America  again, especially watching our current political upheavals ...and yet at the recent Memorial Day services at the Pioneer Cemetery I did feel a unified hope to see us pull our country back  together again.

Comment: The use of freshwater diatomaceous earth (silica) naturally occurring Nevada, Oregon, Washington and California or from freshwater lake (interglacial lakes) deposits occurring in the Eastern United States, Canada, Germany, France, Denmark and the Czech Republic for use as a soil conditioner is recommended over coral dust or marine diatomaceous earth. Freshwater diatomaceous earth like perlite, vermiculite and expanded clay are used as soil conditioners as they retain water and applied nutrients, drain freely and quickly, and allow high oxygen circulation, particularly important for silty clay soils where pineapple has been cultivated, silty loam soils where pangola grass has been planted for pasture, and silty clay soils where sugar cane has been cultivated.

Comment: We're about as far apart politically as possible, but I'll agree that liberalism does indeed own a substantial part of the west coast homeless problem. We have been tolerant of people who are down on their luck and even taxed ourselves to house them. We privately fund programs that feed and clothe people who cannot afford to do so themselves. All of these actions do tend to attract more homeless people from other locales where these programs do not exist. Portland recently revealed that about half of their homeless acknowledge coming from afar, many for the services.

Now I have to wonder if you can acknowledge that conservatism has also played a role. Most bankruptcies are medical in nature, and there is no doubt that conservatives have been in the way of universal health insurance. Minimum wage used to pay for housing, but wasn't indexed to inflation until recently (at a sub-living level). 

And outside of ideology, we do have many homeless who are voluntarily unhoused, aka lazy.

Comment: I remember when a 22 car derailment burned for the greater part of a week within 12 miles of our house in Lowell Oregon, and all roads in and out of town were blocked: Northshore Drive (Pengra) was blocked by accidents of trucks trying to take alternative routes, while Hwy 58 was blocked by authorities both at the MP 14 and MP 12.  The cargo was nominally "methanol," but it tested out as varnish solvent, including MEK--methyl ethyl ketone.   The emergency agancies didn't know what the hell methanol was, and even if it it was water soluble or not.  DEQ, and most state agencies, were AWAL.  DEQ "analyses" declared that the spill did not contain flammable solvents--actually these were repackaged analyses of the RR consultants.  Nevertheless, the "non-flammable solvents" burned for the greater part of a week--as observed by residents.   The RR (then SP) sent out its legal team:  the SP counsel informed me that people south of 58 claiming methanol in their wells "practiced witchcraft."

Comment: Gore was not wrong.  Some sea ice specialists were saying that we might see a summer melt out that early.  As I said earlier, one of the leading researchers stated (IIRC) as early as 2016 +/- 3 years.  2016 - 3 = 2013.  

There's no way to predict the exact year we'll see the first melt-out.  There's a lot of year to year variation in terms of storm timing and intensity, cloud cover, etc.  The best scientists can do is to set a range of likely years.  2016 +/- three was a very aggressive prediction.  Others were predicting 2025 to 2035.  And a few sticking with the 'not for 100 years'. 

I've been watching the ice data closely for the last 10 (?) and as I said to some other people a few days ago, only a fool would bet that we won't see a melt out this year.

I am not predicting the ice will melt out this year.  I'm saying that it's looking very possible.  And that's what Gore was reporting that ice specialists were  saying back in 2007.

Comment: Usually, no one will know the cause of the crash until the NTSB and FAA are done with their investigation.  Sometimes even then,  the reasons will never be known.  There are many possibilities that run the gamut from mechanical failure to pilot error (stall/spin) caused by inescapable high terrain, etc.  One thing that has always been of concern is that for some of those involved in the investigation (given the expertise needed in aviation), it allows parties that could arguably have a conflict of interest to be a part of it. such as powerplant and airframe manufacturers.

Comment: I think there are several elephants in the room (1) the interest rates that really matter to Canadians - mortgage rates and business loan costs - are way more influenced by U.S. capital markets than Canada's central bank rate, and these rates have already gone up. The Bank of Canada has no influence on this. (2) monetary policy when the bank rate is this low is proving itself toothless (except for transient effect on the exchange rate) so this obsessive interest on what the Bank of Canada does is misplaced nostalgia. (3) the really difficult issue facing the Bank of Canada is what will drive the domestic economy as household debt is a serious risk and exports (and investment) are seriously disappointing. The main question for Canadians is when will public opinion insist on fiscal action by the Trudeau government.

the most obvious question to an unlimited amount of solar on the grid is where is all that power going to go when solar power generation exceeds demand? asking yourself that question should tell you whoever said the grid is capable of handling unlimited addition of solar panels is full of bs.

power has to go somewhere. excess power generally creates heat and higher frequencies. that in turn starts to cause equipment damage based on tolerances. sensitive equipment such as consumer electronics are usually the first to go. then the domino effect gets started as there is no longer a demand from broken equipment which increases the ratio of power generation over demand. btw, this all starts to happen in mere seconds.

people who travel internationally can probably tell you what happens when you accidentally plug in your 110v device into a 220v socket without a switching power supply. poof! the same principle happens on the grid.

Comment: New America Foundation, a DC think tank did an analysis of "homegrown extremism" since 2000. It compiled data on 499 extremists, who either adhered to jihadist ideology or were motivated by political beliefs. This database includes attacks & those accused of terrorism-related offenses, e.g plotting attacks or fundraising.  New America found that about 64% of the extremists were U.S.-born citizens & 80% were either American-born or naturalized citizens. The database shows 8 of 499 extremists were illegal residents; all 8 were jihadists.  A NY Times analysis found that half of the jihadist attacks since 2001 were committed by US born males. Many others were naturalized citizens. Some were noncitizens but were traveling legally, e.g Richard Reid, the attempted shoe bomber in 2001, (didn’t need a visa was from Britain).

Comment: "Open-mike" , address anything you like, "non-agenda" public input is a guaranteed waste of both time and energy.  By definition it is not focused on the issues which were deemed important enough to be placed on the agenda.  If dozens of speakers all addressed the same non-agenda issue,  for example, the "downtown problems", then the Council, clearly, should have already scheduled a "work shop"/public input session specifically to address that issue.  It's far more responsive to focus a workshop session on a issue, then to take two hours of a meeting theoretically focused on other agenda items and start it with public comments which are, again by definition, "off-topic.,"  A responsive public body recognizes the intensity of public concern and acts to incorporate such concern in a constructive, focused fashion.  The current procedure doesn't really respond to public concern, if anything, IMO, it trivializes it by failing to provide the opportunity for focused, topical input.  Gary Crum

Comment: "News is part of the profit line on TV stations. They always have been."

Not true. Prior to 1977, there was a clear line between news and entertainment, with the former treated as necessary to demonstrating the networks' commitment to serving the public interest; that service was a condition of their license to use the "public airwaves." As a result, news divisions were allowed--in fact expected--to lose money. That changed in 1977, when Roone Arledge, then the head of ABC sports, moved into his new role leading the network's news division, bringing the kind of splashy promotion and ratings-centric philosophy that had been a primary driver of sports television. It was all downhill from there.

So while it is true that news is relatively inexpensive to produce and news operations are now expected to pull their own weight, that does not have to be the case. It is just that public service is no longer considered valuable.

Comment: STW
Treasury Board: compensation in the private equals compensation in the public sector for the same work. 

Now your other points.
I remembered a 1980 ad in the Globe (you owe $6 billion to the special indexed public service pension plan). The same day an editorial said how unfortunate that only the public sector could afford indexing. You suggest that. I had a look. Two points.

The deficit was due to under funding. The 1980 Actuarial Report shows a cost of 4.7% of salary with 2% of salary being deposited. With indexing looking expensive, the private sector had an excuse not to index. Under funding served a purpose.

Inflation decreases purchasing power. Everyone knows that. Inflation also increases interest rates, thus more money flows into pension accounts compensating for the decrease in purchasing power. The employer has a choice, either index pensions or pocket the money. The media never mentions the increase in interest rates. Nor the under funding. I hope that this helps.

Comment: That's not the law.  An officer has no authorization to effect summary justice.  The law is that a police officer may use force reasonable under the circumstances to make a lawful arrest and/or protect the public.  That may include deadly force if an officer, again reasonably,  concludes that it's necessary to protect him/herself or another person from death or serious bodily injury.  In general, police officers, like citizens, must use the minimum force reasonably necessary under the circumstances to accomplish their lawful aim.  

"Weapon" is not a legally precise term.  A firearm an officer happens to know is unloaded may be a weapon, but wouldn't justify deadly force.  On the other hand, a table fork or a piece of cord could, under some imaginable circumstances, be considered a weapon that did justify deadly force.

Comment: Homeland Securty -- "Naturalization Through Military Service: Fact Sheet
Special provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) authorize U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) to expedite the application and naturalization process for current members of the U.S. armed forces and veterans. Generally, qualifying military service includes service with one of the following: Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, Coast Guard and National Guard. In addition, spouses of members of the U.S. armed forces who are or will be deployed may be eligible for expedited naturalization. Other provisions of the law also allow certain spouses to complete the naturalization process abroad.

Comment: As a conservative, I don't care what color or religion any immigrant is, providing that they have the necessary qualifications to make their life in Canada a success and for them  to contribute positively to our economy. I do not care if they wear turbans, kilts or niqabs, providing that they are tolerant of those who choose not to do so. 
There is an obvious need for increased immigration - we have an aging population and a low birthrate and we need young people to come here to pay taxes to support the many programs that are in trouble.  However, it seems that our immigration policy is increasingly attracting far too many people who are likely to be a burden as opposed to a benefit to our economy. Rather than helping us fund much needed programs to help those Canadians who need them, they are making matters worse. 
I am confident that this is the attitude and belief of most conservatives and I hope that we will elect a leader who is not scared to say this.

Comment: I live very near the proposed development, and am frustrated by my fellow neighbors who are continually trying to put road blocks in the progress of developing Frognal Estates. Having recently dealt with the extremely competitive housing market myself, it has become abundantly clear how desperate this area is for supply. Young families like my own are finding it nearly impossible to afford a home, especially one with any sort of yard space for children. The home we ended up purchasing has no yard and was really one of the only we could afford. Frognal Estates will have yards, even if small ones. I personally would consider buying one if they are within our price range. The people I have spoken with regarding this neighborhoods development seem truly concerned with their own housing values, and their alleged concerns regarding slide issues unfounded. They do not have a right to tell a landowner he cannot legally develop his own property.

Comment: I posted support Lynn.   In concept I completely buy into single payer.  In reality, I think there is a very real risk of payoffs and rewards at the provider levels though.   For instance, a list of possible drugs for treatment may lead to a payoff to make such a list.     How many votes can be won by offering services without any receprical effort from a patient dying of 'bad habits'.  

Maybe I'm too pessimistic, but when somebody has to write the regulation and small detail of who pays what, for what treatment, we would have to keep that out of the hands of the political body.    We know as fact that favored status can always be purchased from the less that honorable in Congress or Statehouse.   In many cases it's a decision supported by The Party, giving lots of people cover within the Party structure. 

Single payer is fine, but independent and rational leadership is critical.  I'd like to see regional options as the next step.   We need a prototype.  Big is very clumsy.

Comment: Gravity.

Observation: I am not floating out of my chair.
Test: When I let go of my pen, it falls to the floor, and then rolls under my desk.
Measure: I can time how long it takes to fall to the floor, I can measure the mass of the pen, and calculate the acceleration.

No matter how many times I do it, my pen always falls on the floor. It has never jumped up in the air. That is why we have the law of universal gravitation.

You have no idea what a scientific theory is. And don't bring up buoyancy, as buoyancy doesn't exist without gravity.

Comment: I agree.  I have never understood why people are allowed to deduct interest on 2nd homes either. People can buy an RV or popup trailer and call it a "2nd home" and deduct interest on the loan.  No, I'm not making that up.  I'm guessing the 2nd home deduction is because many Congress members, at one time at least, had 2 homes, one in their district, one in DC.  But that's another topic for another day.

We just can't afford to subsidize high mortgages and high local taxes.  We don't subsidize the entire cost of sending kids to college - that tax credit is $2500.  We don't subsidize the entire cost of raising kids.  We don't subsidize all of people's healthcare costs (frankly, the amount we allow for that deduction is too low, imo). We limit how much people can shelter for retirement.  There are many areas that the tax code allows some deduction in order to encourage a particular activity, but not unlimited amounts for people to spend on that activity because they can afford it.

Comment: There is a fundamental response that is at the bottom of good economics - put all the resources to work. Think of all the unemployed and the underemployed. The government through building essential infrastructure goods and services can use all the idle labour, just as we did during World War 11 at the end of the depression. The creation of long lasting public goods, is public wealth creation. The jobs produce taxes, more consumption, more bank loans and private economic activity. The reduction in unemployment and poverty reduces the pressure on governments at all levels. The full employment helps reduce social pathology, and gives youth the opportunities they need. Currently youth unemployment is double the Canadian rate. A job meets the essential needs of feeling valued and making a contribution. 

Full employment reduces social division, and reduces the attraction of right wing, authoritarian populism.

Comment: Puerto Rico's debt is about equal to the costs accrued to Puerto Rico owing to the Jones Act, effectively a tariff paid to US shipping companies. I believe I told you this before, but you apparently didn't absorb the fact, or don't care to acknowledge it. Only Congress can repeal the Jones Act, and Congress, whether under Democratic or Republican control, has never been sympathetic to Puerto Rico, which has 45% unemployment and a median household income of $18,000, about half what the rest of the US enjoys.

Puerto Rico's debt-to-GDP ratio is 68%, while the US as a whole is around 100%. Most of PR's 70 billion debt is a result of issuance of bonds, which were used to balance its budget since 1973. PR's bonds were attractive to investors because, by law, interest payments were exempt for federal, state and local taxes anywhere in the US. By 2006, Congress had eliminated those exemptions. The indirect effect was depression and corporate flight along with 80,000 jobs lost. (WIKI)

Comment: GOP Leaders Promise Dissenters That Senate Will Gut Essential Health Benefits

As the clock ticked down on Wednesday, Republican leaders made a new promise to the dissenters: that the Senate will add a provision gutting Obamacare's Essential Health Benefits (EHB) rule once the House passes the bill and sends it their way.


The EHB rule, which the current House GOP repeal bill retains, requires that insurance plans have to cover a basic minimum of health care services, including emergency room visits, hospitalization, outpatient services, maternity care, mental health and substance abuse services, prescription drugs, rehabilitative and habilitative services, lab tests, preventive care like vaccines, and vision and dental care for children.

https://www.healthcare.gov/coverage/what-marketplace-plans-cover/

A Critical Evaluation of the Effects of Safe Injection Facilities 
Garth Davies, Simon Fraser University

Conclusion: Taking Causality Seriously
On the subject of the effects of SIFs, the available research is overwhelmingly positive. Evidence can be found in support of SIFs achieving each of the goals listed at the beginning of the evaluation. Comment: Mayors can absolutely impact the climate, for better or for worse. Mayors can appoint forward thinking leaders to city departments to evaluate how we can: switch to greener practices in our city operations, improve transportation/transit options, maintain/improve green spaces, and incentivize businesses/residents to adopt renewable energy. Mayors can also oppose inefficient policies, as well as support legislation that reduces waste (e.g., plastic bag ban). 

While Kent's impact may seem like a drop in the bucket, we must do our part. Other cities are uniting and we are missing out on the knowledge shared around how to optimize public buildings and infrastructure, reduce energy demand, support stronger building/energy codes. Of course the Mayor must also ensure that Kent is a safe & livable city in the near term, that it has adequate public services and a strong financial position, etc. - these are all important things, but inaction around climate change is simply irresponsible.

Hoa

Comment: Obviously the primary factor was the exceptionally heavy rainfall but the Project 2014 decision made a difficult situation even worse.

For example, I purchased a memorial bench for my late wife at our favourite park beside the lake.

A combination of disasters - the exceptional spring rainfall, the tides destroying the breakwater/barrier next to the bench location, and Project 2014 - combined to raise the water level to about four feet which submerged the entire bench and area several weeks ago.

In recent days, the water surrounding the bench is down to about 10 centimeters.

If the lake had been drained as it normally is early in the year, there would be no water in the location of the bench by now.

And the park could be open by now.

If you had actually read what I posted above, you would understand that I said the Obama initiative had added about 10 centimeters to the water level.

Like most of his initiatives, it made things worse rather than better.

Comment: Yep, that describes both ACES and the oil giveaway formerly known as SB21--both assumed oil prices would never fall.  My stupid self could never have predicted how quickly wind, solar, supercharger stations, China's downturn, and natural gas would kill the price of oil.  But they did.

The oil giveaway is the immediate cause of the current budget crisis--but the reasons behind the oil giveaway remain valid, namely that there needs to be a mechanism to encourage small, high-risk operations like Anadarko over a range of oil price conditions.

  My unstable older brother once had a "sledge hammer party" when his car was not running well.  Charged $5 or so to hit the car a few times with a sledge.  It was a big party (this was 1975 or so...) with kegs and much barfing.  I was 10.

Comment: The state is still focused on the wrong type of tourism.
We should focus on high-end tourism not mass tourism.
High-end tourists have a smaller environmental footprint and spend more money.
High-end tourism is built around small boutique hotels, not huge ugly Disney Aulani-type developments.  After all these years, how come we still allow these monstrosities to be built right on the beach?
Check out the photos: goo.gl/2XU7Py
We should crack down on short-term vacation rentals – they do little to boost our economy.  They explain why visitor arrivals are going up, but visitor spending is not.
We should consider a long-term program, tied to the need to retreat from the ocean because of sea-level rise –now projected at 5 to 8 feet by the end of this century- to tear down huge resorts and replace them with smaller, more eco-sensitive hotels.  For example, the ugly concrete bunker at Turtle Bay should be dynamited and replaced with something smaller aimed at the high rollers.

I wondered if I'd have been as afraid if the men had been white, Asian or Hispanic.

My instinctive fear, and the realness of myself as a target, and the reinforcing of stereotypes--it all makes me feel so bad--bad for the officers whose fear led them to take innocent lives, bad for all the black boys who have to live their whole lives labeled as a threat when all they really are is husbands, and fathers and children. One black rapist doesn't make the whole culture dangerous, anymore than one vapid woman makes the whole gender stupid.

That said, I think I'll run somewhere else for a while.

Comment: The Globe and Mail, and indeed most/all of the news sites, do this every single quarter that Stats. Can. releases such a report.  There are dozens of pieces of data in this quarterly report but the G&M only ever reports on one piece and takes the most dim view of it.

The 'household debt service ratio' bit is an important piece of this puzzle and really explains WHY household debt is increasing: People are able to afford it better.  As much as the doom and gloom crowd keep claiming that the end is nigh people are actually spending near record-low amounts to maintain that debt, which kind of flies in the face of the notion that some massive implosion is imminent.

Certainly a lot could change IF interest rates go up by any significant amount, but I don't think anyone should hold their breath for that one.

Comment: "Mr. Trudeau said his government is a "full supporter" of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, when in fact it has repeatedly (and wisely) hedged about clauses that appear to give native people the right to declare unilateral independence, and to veto development."

Let's not fail to mention the not unimportant impediment the constitution poses where these matters are concerned, which must surely be inconvenient to Trudeau, who's prone to wrap himself in the sanctity of that document when it serves him to do so. There is no route for aboriginal independence under the current version of the constitution, which subsumes the Proclamation of 1763, whereby Crown sovereignty is asserted across all Canadian lands. And the Supreme Court recently threw cold water on the fantasy of an aboriginal veto over development. The UNDRIP is at best an aspirational instrument and the big concern should be that Trudeau is creating expectations that can't be met.

Comment: The PERS unfunded mandate issue was created by the public employers...not the public employees.  When, during the years of hyper-inflation, employees agreed to the "PERS pick-up" instead of the applicable COLAs, the employers chose to pay the employee accounts at the time of retirement and not to "double" their PERS contributions each month and "keep up" by so doing.   By doing so, they created a growing deficit.  Had they funded immediately there would have NO money needed at the time of an individual's retirement...it would have already been in the account and "growing" along with the other half.  Instead, the amount due at retirement reflects the growth in the individual's account...only half of which is really there.  That matching amount has to be funded at retirement by contract.  This was a massive mistake.....but, it was the legislature and the public employers who made it....not the public employees.  Gary Crum

Comment: The target inflation indicator of the Bank of England, the UK HICP, aka the CPI, is dysfunctional, not incorporating owner-occupied housing costs in its measure, or more particularly housing prices. Even Carney recognizes excluding OOH costs as a defect of the UK CPI, although since David “Get Out of” Dodge was his mentor, he doesn’t see at all that excluding housing prices is a defect. The best monthly UK inflation indicator now available is the RPI excluding mortgage interest and council tax; its inflation rate was 3.3% in September, down from 3.4% in August, and it has been above or at the 3% upper bound since April. So the idea that the UK has just hit 3% inflation and it is a one-month blip, as suggested by Reuters, is simply delusional.

Comment: Easy to calculate your calories, there are free sites online to assist you.  Once you get the daily calories intake based on your age, height and activity level you go from there. The truth is that people can eat more or less than the recommended daily calories and although I am an active senior and swim laps 3 times a week I eat about 1650 calories on a swim day and 1550 on the other days and I stay at my IBW. That is a bit below the 2000 daily level but that is the way it is. I also saw another way to quickly access your calorie needs and that is an active person can consume 12 calories per pound a day per body weight and inactive person can consume 10 calories per pound a day in body weight. The fun part is to do some of the math on the calories charts and one will find that eating as little as 200 calories per day beyond what your body can use will result in a lot of weight gain. Who knew?

Comment: My entire career in the oil patch trades was as an independent contractor and I was always able to charge top dollar. If no Canadian company was prepared to pay my rate I would find employment offshore at whatever rate I was charging at the moment.

After 30 years of experience with 3 trades tickets and several years as a drilling rig manager I really boosted my hourly rates and no longer worked offshore. Many employers choked at my quotes and looked elsewhere but the Canadian oil patch is really a rather small world and my reputation and capabilities were such that I was almost always in work at my quoted rates.

A couple of times I was called to fix a mess caused by a contractor who was chosen after my initial quote was refused. In those two instances I boosted my hourly rate even higher for the repair fix. Thereafter those 2 companies meekly accepted my hourly rate for any maintenance shutdown or plant certification where I was required.

NEVER sell yourself short.

Comment: This goes way beyond Alaskan politics.  A good economist and political advisor could have seen the plummet in oil prices due to impending world events .
Alaska wouldn't be the first state or country to entice others to come for the resources and share in the wealth.  The problem is, if Alaska didn't modify its taxation structure with big oil, the jobs you all are talking about that might be leaving, would already be gone.  Something to consider.  States cannot force big companies to take the risk if there isn't a big reward.  Like others, perhaps we need to look to consumerism, diversification and incremental changes as our solution instead of relying on the oil money chasm.   
The price of oil will return - then what will the rewards become, and for how long? 
If anything this was a good kick in the left and right butt cheeks of the same congressional unit, looking toward the future of Alaska.  
But this us vs. them bipartisan crap will only alienate each other, and dangerously so.

Comment: "Rein in Kirkland's growth" is exactly what so many of us are thinking/feeling these days.  I'm a longtime resident who is absolutely appalled by what gets approved for development in our city.  I've attended meetings, neighborhood alliance discussions - Yet, when the time comes to vote on a project, or give the stamp of approval, the quality of life for current residents is never considered. The plans to turn the Houghton Center into a Juanita Village should not go forward.  The traffic is so bad in that spot in the summer it's unbearable.  Even in the dead of winter, it's a parking lot.  Kirkland's City Council and Planning Commission need to think of the residents (for once) and leave this area as a neighborhood- A place to call home.  Not another blocked artery in the city.  The developers who are pushing so hard for this to go through = They'll be on their way to the next development, counting their cash, while we sit in traffic, wishing we lived somewhere else.

Comment: One of the things about these articles is the general lack of real numbers one might use to make a comparison. For example, the closest one in this article is that the company is investing 6 B pounds into the Hornsea area development. Using a conversion of 2:1 for CAD : British pound and assuming that includes a full capacity build of 5 GW that works out to $2.40 CAD per watt ($12 B CAD/5 GW). If the build covered is only the 2.6 GW now in the construction phase, the unit cost is still competitive at $4.61. Compare that with Site C in BC:  probably at least $10 B CAD for 1.1 GW works out to $9.09 CAD/watt- hmmm. As I mentioned though, despite the simplicity of this analysis it would be nice to get some solid numbers included in the articles to reduce the fudge factors and "spin" opportunities- on both sides of the argument.
